reviewText: This is one of those movies that make the end of the week so enjoyable.  You've spent your whole week dealing with people at work, a job you're not so enthused about, all the frustrations of bills and daily aggravations, but at least you have a movie like this to pop in where none of that matters for a while.I give this movie such a high mark because of it's value in that regard.  I know that by Friday night I'm not looking for a "Schindler's List" to watch, not even a semi-serious comedy.  No no, I want the lowest low-brain humor I can possibly find.  The stupid humor, where I can laugh loud and often.  So you see, it's not so much how good the plot is, or the production, but what the movie can do for you.The plot is thus; Dick Nelson (who seems to be a normal guy, but is given all the idiosyncracies of the normal guy by Jeff Jones so that he seems quirky) and his wife Marge are on their way to a vacation in their Station Wagon, when an intergalactic magnet manned by a walking Napoleon charicature named Todd Spengo lifts them off the ground, into space, and onto the miniscule speck of a planet that Spengo rules (prompting the obligatory "It's not the size of your planet, it's how you use it.")What follows is a casserole of Monty Python-inspired humor with a great cameo by Eric Idle who dubs Jones's character anew as "Earth-Dick."  Todd Spengo, played by Jon Lovitz in his last good role, is probably the best source of laughs.  You wonder how the heck this guy manages to rule a planet when he can't complete this verse in a song, "Oh Marge, Oh Marge, my love for you is..."  Not that it matters.  I don't think I've ever laughed harder than at the flash-grenade scene, or when Spengo asks his guards "mutton-chops... or goatee?"Props to Teri Garr too for getting in the spirit of things.  You wonder if this character isn't the antithesis of her trouble-wife character in "Close Encounters of the Third Kind," but then you think "Naaaah."  I like her better in this than "Young Frankenstein" as well.So yes, buy it, watch it.  Don't look to be enlightened, just uplifted.  If silliness like this were more prevalent in the world, I predict we'd have a nicer place to live in.
summary: Turn off your brain and just enjoy!
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Mom and Dad Save the World" is a thinly disguised parody of the "Flash Gordon" series of films.  The Emperor Todd Spengo (a stupid version of Ming the Merciless) plans to destroy the earth, but falls in love with Marge Nelson (a suburban Dale Arden played by Teri Garr) when he sees her through his telescope.Using a hokey '40s-sci-fi-style magnetic ray, he brings Marge and her husband, Dick (the middle-aged Flash Gordon of our tale) to his planet, which is populated almost entirely by stupid people.  The emperor quickly imprisons Dick in order to force Marge to marry him, and then Dick must defeat the emperor, rescue Marge, and save the earth.The bad special effects and the whole "planet of stupid people" concept are both played to the hilt in this clever, but widely underrated comedy.  Jon Lovitz is terrific as emperor Spengo, and Kathy Ireland plays the part she was born for as Semage, princess of the planet of stupid people.  All right, maybe that wasn't fair, but she really was well suited to the part.One of my favorite gags in the film involves a thing called a "flash grenade", which vaporizes anyone who picks it up.  Why, then would anyone pick it up, you ask?  I'd tell you, but that would spoil the joke.  It's amazing how effective a weapon that stupid can be on a planet full of stupid people.High art, this ain't, but it's cute, funny, and uses its premise very effectively.  Hmm...  Sounds a bit like I'm just describing Kathy Ireland again...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Well no, it's not a classic by any means.  This is one of those "it's so bad it's good" kind of movies.  I'm not a fan of Jon Lovitz at ALL.  I think those new Subway commercials are some of the WORST commercials ever to air on television.  But this movie starring Jon Lovitz as the "king of the world" is okay.When you think about a title like "Mom and Dad Save the World" your first thought is probably something extremely cheesy.  Well, in this case, the images of cheese and constant silliness is EXACTLY correct.  That's exactly what the storyline is.Mom and dad are kidnapped by people on another planet, and at first, all they want to do is find a way to get out of there and return home to Earth.  However, new "people" come into their lives, so more obstacles get in their way making it harder to return home.  It's an extremely silly movie that's probably not very funny, but I think you will really like it because of SOME reason.My favorite thing are the mushrooms that live in the sewer of the castle.  I also love the friendly fish-face women.  Yes, that sentence makes me look like I'm on drugs, but I'm not.  You might think you're on drugs after this movie is over... and I recommend watching it.

reviewText: There's lots of stuff to enjoy in this little slapstick farce, if you approach it with the attitude its makers intended.  It oozes with intentional ridiculousness.  All the actors brought the proper attitude to  their roles.  It was a blast to watch Lovitz ham it up.  Garr turned out to  be incredibly sexy in one of her outfits.  At least that's how it affected  me.  There's not a whole lot of witty writing, but as a sheer farce, it  works.  Take it that way, and you'll enjoy it.
summary: It's a farce! Lighten up and enjoy it!

reviewText: Dick and Marge Nelson are a typical Earth couple with all the usual disagreements and frustrations of a long marriage.  Not really unhappy, but not especially happy either.  Then Tod, Ruler of Spengo sets out to make Marge his wife...Hilarity ensues.  Dick and Marge set out on a weekend trip when their stationwagon is snatched away to Spengo.  When they are brought before the villianous Tod, the realize Todis an idiot, as are the other inhabitants of Spengo.  Goldfish, bulldogs, the king that Tod deposed, the former king's son and daughter, ambulatory mushrooms with fangs, and a heart-broken torturer work together with Marge and Earth Dick to defeat the evil emperor, reuite Marge and Dick, and confuse the heck out of Marge and Dick's teenage kids.Brilliant comic talents and a light-hearted but well-executed visual style make this an all time great.  The talents of Jon Lovitz, Terri Garr, Jeffry Jones, Wallace Shawn, and (briefly) Eric Idle go without saying, but even Jill Ireland delivers a competent performance.  Thalmus Rasulala deserves special mention as the smartest man on Spengo (still not saying much), Tod's major domo.  His dry delivery is perfect for the supercilious chief of staff to a vain and foolish leader, but when pretending to be hit with a love potion, segues into an ardent admirer of the villain.The styling of the sets and props of Spengo is comic genius,  Exaggeration and whimsy rule the day and complete the tone of the movie.An enjoyable movie for anyone, but doubly enjoyable for parents.E. M. Van Court
summary: The evil emperor Tod versus the Earth Dick!

reviewText: I love this movie.  I remember first watching it at my cousin's house, and it seemed faded in my memory because I was laughing so hard.  This movie is one of those films where you just need to shut everything else out.A couple get beamed up to planet Spengo, where Emperor Tod (Lovitz, in an earlier and more hilarious role) wishes to wed Marge (Garr) and wishes to have Dick (Jones), her husband, killed.The movie has so many funny moments, and even has comedic support by Eric Idle.  I recommend this film to anyone who wants a really deserving laugh.
summary: No, I am Raff, you are Earth Dick.

reviewText: This movie is funnier than intended, but it actually works out. There's lots of fun characters, like Bwaaaa (the fish-woman) and her husband, Bbbblaat (the dog) as well as the evil king who wants to take over the universe, the Earth woman he falls in love with, and her husband who tries to save her. It's a weirs movie, and I saw it a long time ago so I don't remember EVERYTHING, but I do remember enjoying it a lot. It's sci-fi, but not so serious, and is a fun and light-hearted romp with some funny dialogue and plot twists.

reviewText: MOM AND DAD SAVE THE WORLD is really something like a live action Saturday morning cartoon.  It's hopelessly silly but admittedly fun at times.  Jeffrey Jones and Teri Garr star as Dick and Marge Wilson, who are whisked away to the planet of Spingo by its narcissistic king played with unabashed ham by Jon Lovitz.  The planet is "a planet full of idiots" and all its inhabitants live up to it.  Seems Lovitz wants Garr for his Queen and then plans on destroying Earth so his planet can be the greatest in the universe.  Eric Idle has fun playing the vanquished king before Lovitz, and Wallace Shawn steals his brief scenes.  It's pretty childish fun, but some of the creatures are cute and if you just want silly entertainment, this fits the bill.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was another obscure movie that I was lucky enough to catch in theaters on its orignal release.  I was drawn by the sheer goofiness of the title and the cast.The concept is simple.  Stupid Aliens vs Humans of Average Intelligence.  The execution is what makes or breaks a movie, and this one is surpsingly well done.  The sets and props are bizarre, intentionally so.  This is a universe where even the blasters shoot squiggly lasers.The writing is uproariously dumb but witty and sophisticated at the same time.  I know lots of people think these qualities are mutually exclusive, but great comedy (even broad comedy) requires a deft touch to work.  It's hard to explain, since this movie dwells so far in absurdity, but when the smarts are missing, it shows.  Just check out pretty much any film by Shaun and Marlon Wayans for a painful example.  And if you love the Wayans, don't bother with this film.  There's not nearly enough fart jokes for you.My biggest pleasure is finally seeing Jeffrey Jones in a starring part.  He's a talented actor who otherwise plays strong supporting roles.  You'll recognize him, even if you don't know his name.Check it out and laugh at some inspired ridiculousness.
summary: STUPID AND SMART at the same time

reviewText: This is most certainly one of the craziest and funniest of movies around, and, trust me, you'll end up laughing and graning all though the movie. What a hoot .....OK so it's also an adult movie cause Terry Garr, who plays Marge the mom, keeps asking for her husband, Dick, played by bug eyed Jeffry Jones, by calling out lines like 'Has anyone seen my Dick' or 'Where is Dick when you really need it' ......Jon Lovitz who playse the dumb emperor Tod Spengo is absolutely outstanding and in his Saturday Night Live element in this movie..... Oh one more thing, please keep this movie away from the kids because if they see you watching it the will get confirmation of the actual fact that we grownups are a little nuts after all.....
summary: If this isn't camp then I don't know what is ...

reviewText: This movie is supposed to be corny and horribly unreal but that is what makes it so funny!  A tiny undiscovered planet called "Spengo" that lies just outside of our solar system holds a planet of apparent idiots!  These apparent idiots somehow developed a super death ray with all of their wisdom and intellect and the ruling leader, Tod, plans to destroy Earth with it!  However using a super powerful scope he zooms in on Marge, a married woman and falls head over heels in love because Earthlings and Spengols are physically identical, well, some of them are!  In any case he arranges to have her brought to Spengo using a super powerful magnetic tractor beam created with all of Spengo's technological prowess, ha ha ha!  Unfortunately Dick, her husband, was also with her when they were successfully beamed from Earth..but my question is, how are they still alive in their "woody" station wagon with the windows rolled down and traveling through space?!  The tractor beam probably doubles up as a protective barrier from the vacuum of space...I hope so!  In any case this movie is worth watching and has a warm and sweet undertone to it.  It brings me back to my childhood days of goofy 1990's family films.
summary: You can't go wrong with comedy!

reviewText: This is really an adorable movie. It is just a lot of fun. It has no pretensions of being a GREAT movie, or a significant movie, or a movie with a message. The makers of this movie did not set about to make another Gone with the Wind or Godfather.  Just one look at its rating on Rotten Tomatoes will indicate as much. Critics, however, lack humor and sometimes don't see a good thing when they see it, and this is one example.This movie is about the ruler of a small, insignificant planet (Jon Lovitz) falling in love with a suburban wife on earth (Teri Gar), beaming her and her husband (Jeffrey Jones) to his planet, with plans of making her his wife and blowing up earth, thereby becoming ruler of the universe. His plans are foiled (of course), in no small part because he and the inhabitants of the planet are incredibly stupid. What the earth couple encounters, is a marvelous assortment of fish people, bulldog people, special effects, crazy characters, dead pan humor -- Lovitz is especially inspired in this department --and just plain fun. The performances work so well that it bears repeated viewings, a relative rarity in most films.This movie works incredibly well as a childrens movie -- but there is enough for grown ups to appreciate. There are numerous, subtle references (critiques?) of suburban life circa 1990. Even the score by Jerry Goldsmith appears to be a reference to movie soundtracks ala Star Wars. There is truly something for everyone in this movie.
summary: The Movie Doesn't Take Itself Seriously and So Should You.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was supposed to be John Lovitz's breakout film and why it wasn't is anybody's guess. What you have here is a hilarious screwball comedy adaptation of Flash Gordon where suburban Mom and Dad are kidnapped and hauled to the alien planet...in their station wagon (a primitive form of SUV). Teri Garr and Jeff Jones as the "folks" give their usual great performances (really, neither has ever done anything less than a first rate job in any movie) and Lovitz is sensational as Emperor Todd. Plenty of good additional cast members and highly imaginative costumes and sets add to the entertainment.The level of comedy is great. A favorite moment in this film (and a favorite film moment altogether) is when the family station wagon--zipping through space pulled by a magnetic beam--passes the planet Saturn and "mom" takes a Kodak photo of it using the flash. That's a joke that's subtler than it looks and this sort of slapstick/thoughtful (and plenty of satire) runs through the whole movie. It's dopey but it's smart dopey.They've resurrected the brilliant, stunning, wondrous, amazing "Freaked!" from this era (Oh, don't we long for those good old days--late Eighties to late Nineties!) and the DVD of that should go right to the top of any comedy lover's want list. It's time to get this fun film back in circulation because we sure as heck need good laughs these days!
Title: N/A
